title-group.article-title: Multi-frequency modelling of unsteady flow in the inlet manifold of an internal combustion engine

abstract.p: Pressure wave propagation in the inlet and exhaust manifolds of internal combustion engines is an important phenomenon which affects the filling and emptying of the cylinders. The objective of this paper is to present a new methodology that takes into account this phenomenon without the use of a one-dimensional resolution scheme. First, an analogy is made between the compressible air in a pipe and a mechanical ideal mass–damper–spring system. A multi-frequency model is then presented. The principle of the model is to define a link between the pressure and the flow velocity by means of the impedance. The parameters of this model can be determined using a flow bench working in unsteady conditions and called the ‘dynamic flow bench’. The new model is then tested with a more complex geometry. The latter corresponds to a specific air intake system of an internal combustion engine. It is then possible to introduce the new model into an internal combustion engine simulation code and to compare the numerical results with the experimental data. Good agreement is obtained between the two, and the new multi-frequency model appears to be an alternative method for modelling the pressure waves in the intake and exhaust systems of internal combustion engines. It is therefore possible to reduce the computational times.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: In the inlet and exhaust systems of internal combustion engines, unsteady flows take place; these phenomena are due to the opening and closing of the valves [1–3] and are also caused by unsteady elements in nature (such as the turbine and the compressor) which are located in the pipe systems [4], [5]. As a consequence, the volumetric efficiency of the engine can be modified owing to the effect of the pressure waves on the filling and emptying of the cylinders [6–11]. In order to study their influence on the engine behaviour, computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations can be made. However, the design of the inlet and exhaust systems is generally complex and this kind of study rapidly becomes a time-consuming procedure. As a consequence, many researchers have decided to use a one-dimensional approach by solving gas dynamics equations in pipe elements. During their PhD studies, a complete literature survey was made by Kirkpatrick [12] and by Chalet [13]. These gas dynamics equations are obtained from the continuity equation
the momentum equation
and the energy equation [2]

In order to solve the one-dimensional equations in pipe elements, different techniques can be used, e.g. the method of characteristics [14], the acoustic method [5], and the finite difference method with different numerical schemes [15]. The improvement in the computational tools provides the possibility of using all these methods, and it is then possible to develop some models which consider physical phenomena [5], [16], [17]. Generally, total-variation-diminishing (TVD) numerical schemes are used in order to solve this system of equations [13], thus eliminating numerical oscillations. Then, the main difficulty consists in defining the boundary conditions of these pipes. The modelling of the various boundary conditions at the inlet and outlet of the different elements that make up an internal combustion engine still remains quite challenging. As a consequence, CFD codes [18], [19] and experimental apparatus [20] are generally used in order to analyse the fluid around the boundaries of the system, and one-dimensional models are developed. It is then possible to include the models in laboratory internal combustion engine software which describes the complete engine behaviour [13]. Today, this one-dimensional approach is also included in many commercial internal combustion engine software such as GT-Power, Ricardo Wave, AVL Boost, and LMS Amesim. The equations in these codes are solved by a finite volume approach.

However, even if the one-dimensional approach is a good tool, the complex air intake system of an internal combustion engine implies an increase in the simulation time. Another technique consists in using the acoustic method [14], which considers the fluid to be non-viscous and assumes isentropic evolution. All the equations can be combined with the ideal-gas state equation. Finally, only one equation describes the fluid evolution in the pipe elements. The disadvantage of this methodology is that velocity fluctuations must remain low in comparison with the speed of sound. However, some workers use frequency analysis in order to study the volumetric efficiency of an internal combustion engine. In order to obtain the frequency spectrum of the pipe systems, different experimental techniques have been developed [22–24]. A direct relation between the pressure and the velocity, i.e. between the excitation and the system effect on the fluid flow, is highlighted. It is then possible to imagine a new formulation of fluid flow in the intake and exhaust manifolds of internal combustion engines which can reduce the computational times and can be used to study the filling and emptying of an engine.

sec.title: 2 Mechanical Analogy and New Model
sec.p: The intake or exhaust manifold of an internal combustion engine can be seen as excited by the opening and closing of the valves. The objective, with equation (7), is then to define the pressure evolution near the valve with the response to air mass flow excitation. In order to develop a new model, it is considered that the compressible air is equivalent to a spring. In a pipe, the air could be characterized by the mass, and the viscous effects are similar to a damper. With this analogy to a mechanical system, it is then possible to determine the pressure evolution in a pipe. sec.title: 3.1 Experimental set-up
sec.p: In order to identify the different parameters of the new model, which depend on the frequencies of a pipe system, an experimental set-up is used. This solution is chosen because the use of a CFD code requires an intensive computing time. The objective of the dynamic flow bench is to generate a pressure wave in a pipe system from the variation in the air mass flow. The advantage of this device is that it allows a level of pressure fluctuations comparable with that observed in an internal combustion engine.

The principle of the dynamic flow bench is to create an initial steady flowrate through the tested part and then to interrupt the flow very quickly in approximately 0.5 ms. This fast closing generates strong pressure waves, which are measured at the outlet of the tested system and analysed in the frequency domain by fast Fourier transform (FFT). The experimental set-up is presented in Fig. 1. Initially, this device is used in order to obtain a steady flow in the studied system 1. In this objective, a Superflow SF600 flow bench is used. This element is connected to the experimental test bench 5. The fluid travels from the studied system to the flow bench via an Sierra 780 S air mass flow meter 4. When the flow is stabilized, the dynamic component 2 is used in order to interrupt the flow.

It is common in acoustic studies to calculate the velocity fluctuations from pressure measurements. However, the multi-transducer wave decomposition needs to make experiments with small perturbations of the pressure signal because it is based on an acoustic formulation. In fact, the objective is to obtain a linear problem. In this experimental set-up, the pressure variations are too important and, as a consequence, the shape of the excitation component was developed in order to obtain a linear decrease in the air mass flow from the initial value of 1 to 0 (in 0.5 ms). In order to maintain a flow in the flow bench, a bypass system 3 is used at the same time as the excitation component. This experimental set-up is controlled by a computer 6 and the pressure signals are recorded and plotted 7. Pressure signals are measured using Kistler 4045A2 piezoresistive transducers. The output from each pressure transducer is pre-amplified and filtered into a National Instruments PCI-6071E board.

sec.title: 3.2 The 1 m pipe analysis
sec.p: A straight tube of constant section is the simplest acoustic element that can be analysed. For this reason, a simple tube is characterized first (a pipe 1 m long with an internal diameter of 30 mm). This element is installed in the experimental set-up. The experimental principle is therefore to impose an air mass flowrate in the pipe. In this paper, the flow is set to 150 kg/h. Then the flow is interrupted by a quick valve. Throughout this time, the instantaneous pressure is measured at a distance of 45 mm from the quick valve, with a frequency of 20 kHz. The results are plotted in Fig. 2.

caption.p: Evolution of the pressure near the dynamic component

sec.p: The first part of the curve corresponds to the steady state condition of the test. It is then possible to measure the pressure losses of the system which can be included in the model (pressure ploss). For this mass flowrate, the pressure losses are equal to 25 mbar. Next, the pipe is excited by the variation in the mass flowrate. As a consequence, a pressure wave is generated. The time evolution of the pressure depends on the pipe characteristics. For this reason, the FFT of this pressure signal is calculated. It is then possible to define the resonant frequency f1 of the pipe and its harmonics fi. The resonant frequency is equal to 82 Hz and the harmonics are equal to 247 Hz, 412 Hz, 578 Hz, 745 Hz, and 909 Hz. The acoustic theory [14] gives the resonant frequency (and its harmonics) of a straight pipe. For a pipe opened at one end and closed at the other, these frequencies are calculated as

It then appears that the length of the tube and the temperature (used in order to calculate the speed of sound) are the main parameters that influence most of these frequencies. The experimental test is made with an air temperature of 19 °C. In this condition, the theoretical frequencies are calculated (as shown in Table 1). These results are quite different from the experimental data. This is due to the connection of the 1 m pipe with the dynamic component which is made with a 25 mm tube. It is therefore important to correct the results of characterization. For this objective, equation (16) is used. It is assumed that the temperature is constant. sec.p: All the results are given in Table 1. Finally, it appears that the experimental frequencies are similar to those obtained with the acoustic analysis. The differences are explained by the non-perfect reflection of the pressure wave at the open end boundary of the pipe. A spherical wave is generated outside the pipe. Bruneau [25] explained that the frequencies obtained are equivalent to those obtained with a longer length of the pipe. Several studies have led to a correction term length defined in references [26] to [29]. One of these corrections consists in increasing the pipe length by a length equal to 0.3 D.

The experimental set-up also provides the possibility of calculating the impedance relating the pressure response to the excitation. In mechanics, a second-order differential equation such as equation (10) corresponds to an under-damped system. This combines oscillations at a specific frequency with a decrease in the amplitude of the signal. In physics and engineering, the damping ratio characterizes the resonator’s bandwidth relative to its centre frequency. A lower damping ratio indicates a lower rate of energy loss relative to the stored energy of the oscillator (the oscillations die more slowly). The relationship between the bandwidth and the damping ratio is then [30]

In this equation, Amax corresponds to the value of the impedance when the pulsation is equal to the resonant frequency. This principle is extended to the harmonic frequencies. As a consequence, the damping ratio for each frequency is calculated from

The modulus of the impedance is plotted in Fig. 3. This figure shows the importance of the harmonics, which are not negligible. This point seems to be important and is investigated in the next part of this paper. It is now possible to obtain a graphic resolution to determine the damping ratios εi. For each frequency, the value of Amax is measured and, as a consequence, the damping ratio is calculated. All the results are given in Table 1.

The last coefficients to be determined are the inertia parameter and the weight factor. First, an initial inertia parameter is chosen. Next, equation (14) is solved by considering only one frequency. A comparison between the experimental results and the numerical results (in the time domain) is made. If the results do not coincide, an iterative procedure is used in order to find the correct value of the inertia parameter. Thus the inertia parameter Γ is equal to 1.7 × 105 Pa s2/m. Finally, equation (14) is solved by considering all frequencies, and the weight factors are adjusted in order to obtain the same result (in the time domain) for the experimental results and the numerical results. All the results are given in Table 1.

sec.title: 3.3 Mathematical multi-variable optimization
sec.p: It appears that this geometry is relatively simple to study and the different model parameters can be calculated easily. However, for a more complex geometry, this identification is more difficult. For this reason, an identification process is made by a mathematical multi-variable optimization tool. In this code, the inputs are the air mass flow evolution and the frequencies. Indeed, it is important to conserve the frequencies as an input for the code. As depicted in Fig. 3, the frequency spectrum of the pipe is characterized by the resonant frequency and its harmonics but also by the inter-peaks.

In order to study these inter-peaks, some tests were made with different initial air mass flows. It is important to note that the pressure signal depends on the initial air mass flow. As a consequence, the amplitude of the pressure waves increases with increasing initial air mass flow. Different tests were conducted with initial air mass flows of 10 kg/h, 100 kg/h, and 250 kg/h. As shown in Fig. 4, the inter-peaks increase with increasing initial air mass flow. In fact, this particular phenomenon is due to the non-linear evolution of the flow in the pipe. This is not a pipe characteristic. As a consequence, the frequencies of the inter-peaks are not inputs of the mathematical multi-variable optimization tool.

caption.p: Frequency spectrum of the pipe for different initial air mass flows

sec.p: This kind of code can be used in order to characterize a pipe system and to obtain the damping ratio and the inertia parameter. For the studied pipe, the inertia parameter obtained with this code is the same as the previous inertia parameter (the two values are obtained with an identification process). The damping ratio parameters are then equal to 0.0209, 0.033, 0.046, 0.066, 0.094, and 0.137. These values are quite similar to those obtained with the physical analysis.

sec.title: 3.4 Importance of the frequencies
sec.p: In this paper, the frequency analysis of a simple pipe shows that it is possible to characterize this pipe by frequencies. However, it is important to define whether the model needs all the frequencies. For this objective, the model described by equations (12), (14), and (15) is used with two different configurations. The first configuration is made with the use of only one frequency F1 whereas the second configuration is obtained with three frequencies F1, F2, and F3. The initial air mass flow is equal to 150 kg/h. The pressure signals are calculated and compared with the experimental values.

As depicted in Fig. 5, better agreement is obtained between the experimental result and the numerical results when three frequencies are used in the model. In order to explain these differences, it is important to analyse equation (10). If the inertia of the fluid is negligible (and equal to zero for this analysis), the solution of the equation is

caption.p: Effects of the frequencies on the pressure signals

sec.p: As described before, the damping ratio ε is much smaller than unity. As a consequence, the pseudo-pulsation Ω is similar to the pulsation ω. This solution indicates that the pressure signal is oscillating with a frequency which is quasi-similar to that of the resonant frequency. Furthermore, the amplitude of the pressure waves gradually decreases to zero. This phenomenon is observed for all the curves. In fact, the frequency of 82 Hz corresponds to a time period of 0.012 s. It corresponds to the pressure evolution from 1 s to 1.012 s. As a consequence, the pressure signal obtained with only one frequency in the model is similar (by definition) to a sinusoidal signal. This result is depicted in Fig. 5 by the black curve. This result is not sufficient because the numerical pressure wave signal is quite different from the experimental signal. It is then impossible to reproduce the different pressure steps of the pressure signal. On the other hand, a frequency of 247 Hz corresponds to a time period of 4.05 ms. This phenomenon makes it possible to create another sinusoidal signal which is superimposed on the first signal. It is then possible to represent the pressure steps. However, the oscillations are too important and a third frequency is used (412 Hz). This last signal corresponds to a time period of 2.4 ms. As depicted in Fig. 5, another sinusoidal signal is superimposed on the result. This result tends to create the pressure step and correct agreement is obtained between the experimental results and the simulation results. Therefore, it is very important to integrate more than one frequency in the model if the objective is to reproduce the pressure waves correctly.

sec.title: 4 A More Complex Configuration
sec.p: It appears that a multi-frequency model is a good tool for describing the pressure wave in a pipe system. However, for a more complex configuration, it could be difficult to determine the physical frequencies which can be used by the identification code. For this reason, another configuration is studied. The objective here is to analyse the pressure spectrum of the new configuration and to define the inputs of the code. The tested geometry is a ‘tube–volume–tube’ system. It is composed of a straight pipe (with a length of 1010 mm and a diameter of 30 mm) which is connected to a volume. In fact, this volume is a pipe of larger diameter (with a length 400 mm and a diameter of 120 mm). This pipe is then connected to another pipe (with a length of 225 mm and a diameter of 30 mm). In order to characterize this system, the dynamic flow bench is used (Fig. 1). The pipe system is connected to the experimental set-up by the longer pipe. The pressure signal is recorded at 45 mm from the beginning of the long pipe.

The results are plotted in Fig. 6 (dashed curve) and compared with those of the simple tube configuration (solid curve). Before 0.1 s, the air mass flow is travelling through the pipe system and it is then possible to determine the pressure losses ploss. As observed in Fig. 6, the pressures losses of the tube–volume–tube configuration are higher than those of the simple pipe. There are two reasons. The first reason concerns the length of the systems. The tube–volume–tube system is longer than the simple tube and, as a consequence, the frictional forces on the fluid are higher. The second reason is due to the variation in the cross-sectional area. These physical properties affect the pressure losses because some vortices appear and energy is used in order to maintain them. At t = 0.1 ms, the air mass flow through the system decreases from 150 kg/h to 0 kg/h. A pressure wave is then generated. This is propagated into the first pipe. At the other end of the pipe, a reflected wave and a transmitted wave appear. The reflected wave is going to the pipe inlet and is measured by the sensor. This configuration is equivalent to the simple pipe and the pressure signals are nearly the same (as depicted in Fig. 6). The differences are due to the pressure losses which are different. It is also important to note that the lengths are different but the figure scale is inadequate for visualizing this phenomenon. Next, the transmitted wave is propagated into the volume and is also transmitted (in the last tube) or reflected into the volume. As a consequence, the sensor records the pressure wave reflection in the entire tube–volume–tube configuration. It is then interesting to analyse the frequency spectrum of this system. As presented before, it is then possible to calculate the impedance of the pipe system. The modulus of this impedance is plotted in Fig. 7.

Frequency spectrum of the tube–volume–tube configuration

sec.p: The analysis of the curve provides the possibility of identifying different frequencies: 38 Hz, 88 Hz, 246 Hz, 398 Hz, 441 Hz, 577 Hz, and 741 Hz. The pipe of 1.01 m length is characterized by frequencies of 88 Hz, 246 Hz, 398 Hz, 577 Hz, and 741 Hz. It is now important to analyse the frequencies of 38 Hz and 441 Hz. The volume installed in this system could be analysed as a Helmholtz resonance [14]. This phenomenon corresponds to the air resonance in a cavity. This particular frequency is defined by the equation

In this equation, the volume VH is equal to the geometrical volume (a pipe with a length of 400 mm and a diameter of 120 mm), the cross-sectional area AH corresponds to the pipe section (a pipe diameter of 30 mm), and the length LH is equal to the second pipe length (225 mm). The theoretical value of this Helmholtz resonator is equal to 37.9 Hz. This is similar to the experimental result.
Next, the acoustic theory [14] gives the resonant frequency (and its harmonics) of a straight pipe for a pipe open at its two ends. These frequencies are calculated as

The theoretical resonant frequency of the volume (which is in reality a pipe with a larger diameter) is equal to 429 Hz. It appears that the experimental frequency of 441 Hz corresponds to this particular frequency. The differences could be explained by the interaction between this pipe and the other pipes. The resonant frequency of the small pipe is equal to 762.5 Hz. This value is too large and will not be taken into account in this paper.

The mathematical multi-variable optimization tool is then used in order to determine the different parameters of the model. The results are presented in Table 2. In addition, the inertia parameter is identified to be 1.9 × 105 Pa s2/m.

The modelling of the system of pipes seems to be made with a multi-frequency approach. It is now necessary to study whether this kind of modelling can be used for the simulation of an internal combustion engine filling.

sec.title: 5 Engine Simulation
sec.p: The new model can be used in order to simulate pressure wave propagation in an engine manifold and, as a consequence, the air filling and emptying of the engine cylinders. In this paper, the new model is used to simulate a four-stroke one-cylinder engine. The experimental test bench is located in the laboratory. As depicted in Fig. 8, the tube–volume–tube system is connected to the head cylinder of the engine.

caption.p: Tube–volume–tube configuration connected to the internal combustion engine

sec.p: The internal combustion engine is used as a pulse generator. In fact, there is no combustion and the engine is driven by an electric motor. The connection between the cylinder head and the 1 m pipe is obtained with a convergent element 70 mm long (start diameter, 30 mm; end diameter, 19 mm) and a particular element which transforms the circular cross-section into a square cross-section. The inlet port is composed of a pipe (L = 15.75 mm and D = 27.5 mm), a bend (L = 24 mm and a diameter evolution from 27.5 mm to 23.2 mm), and a pipe (L = 8 mm and D = 23.2 mm). The air mass flow is measured with a Sierra 780 S flow meter. In order to measure the average mass flowrate without a pulsating flow, a 200 l tank is connected to the exhaust port of the engine and the air mass flow meter is located at the outlet of the tank.

In order to evaluate the air mass flow through the valves and to calculate the engine filling, a complete simulation of the internal combustion engine is made. In the simulation code (GT-Power in this paper), the rotational speed is imposed. The opening and closing of the valves generates pressure waves in the pipe systems and the air mass flow through the cylinder can be calculated. The simulation code provides the possibility of giving a one-dimensional description of the intake manifold. It is then possible to compare the results obtained with this code with those obtained with the new model.

As a consequence, first, the inlet tube–volume–tube is described by a one-dimensional approach. The pipe is subdivided into meshes of 10 mm. The different elements used to connect the tube–volume–tube to the cylinder head are also described with a one-dimensional approach as well as the tube inside the cylinder head. The engine is characterized by a bore of 64 mm, a stroke of 50 mm, a connecting-rod length of 78.16 mm, and a compression ratio of 8.5.

Second, the tube–volume–tube is described by the new model. This is the only part which is modified in comparison with the previous description. In order to make a link between the time domain and the Laplace domain, the Simulink tool is used. The objective of this section is to link the new model of the air intake system to the engine model using Simulink and GT-Power by a direct coupling method (as depicted in Fig. 9). GT-Power is used to obtain the boundary conditions; at each time step, GT-Power provides the mass flowrate to the Simulink model at the location of the inlet valve, and Simulink calculates the pressure to be applied upstream the inlet valve. The new model is then described in Simulink in the Laplace domain and the ODE45 solver is used in order to solve the equation.

In order to determine the performance of the new model, a direct comparison of the numerical and experimental volumetric efficiencies is made. With this experimental set-up, the air mass flow and the pressure signals are measured for a range from 1500 r/min to 3000 r/min. Figure 10 shows the experimental and the numerical results (GT-Power only and coupled GT-Power Simulink). The volumetric efficiency of the engine is defined by the equation

sec.p: Good agreement is then obtained between the native code and the coupled simulation. Indeed, the shapes of the volumetric efficiency curves seem to be the same but their values differ. However, the differences remain minor and could be considered negligible. As a consequence, this kind of model can be used in order to simulate the pressure wave phenomenon in engine ducting with a reduction in the computational time. The numerical results are also compared with the experimental results. Some differences appear between the numerical results and the experimental data between 2250 r/min and 2500 r/min. In fact, the modelling of the intake system does not justify these differences alone. Filling depends on several factors that have been neglected in the engine modelling. Heat exchanges in the cylinder are not correctly modelled and the adaptation parts of the air mass flow meter are not taken into account. As a consequence, it is then possible to consider that good agreement is obtained between the experimental and numerical results.

sec.title: 6 Conclusion
sec.p: The simulation of pressure waves in inlet and exhaust systems of an internal combustion engine is important in order to determine the filling and emptying of the cylinders. This paper presents a new model which considers the compressible air as a mechanical mass–damper–spring system. It appears that a system of pipes could be characterized by frequencies and these have an influence on the waveform. A multi-frequency model is then developed. This provides the possibility of making a direct link between the pressure and the air mass flow at the end of the pipe by the use of an impedance.

A mathematical multi-variable optimization tool is also developed in order to determine the parameters of the model. The methodology is used for a tube–volume–tube geometry. The different parameters of the model are then defined for this configuration which is installed at the inlet of a one-cylinder engine. Then, the model is used in order to describe the air mass flow through the engine cylinder. There is no combustion in the cylinder (the engine is driven by an electric motor) in order to restrict the study on the sole influence of the pressure waves on the engine’s filling. Good agreement is then obtained between the experimental results and the numerical results. Finally, this kind of modelling can be a good design tool for the intake manifold of an internal combustion engine. The advantage of this new model is a shorter simulation time because the number of equations is reduced in comparison with those for a one-dimensional simulation code. Further investigations will be made in order to determine the parameters of the model without the use of the multi-variable optimization tool. Next, the complete description of an intake manifold will be made with a composition consisting of a simple element.
